G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, because the matter involves a claim for damages appropriately handled in a District Court and occurred in Newton, within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Newton District Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 as the incident giving rise to this action occurred in Newton, Massachusetts, and both parties are residents of the Commonwealth.

Newton City Ordinance \u00a7 3-38.proposition: Oak Hill Park is maintained and regulated by the City of Newton and is subject to posted park rules, including a requirement that all dogs must be kept on a leash in accordance with Newton City Ordinance § 3-38.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60F.proposition: 1. G.L. c. 231, § 60F – Duty of care owed to recreational users.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: 4. **Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) – Standard of care owed by property users to lawful visitors.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is a leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common-law distinction between licensees and invitees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners/occupiers to lawful visitors. The quoted concurring passage criticizes retaining a separate rule for trespassers and reinforces that the majority has changed the standard of care toward lawful entrants. Although this excerpt is from a concurrence and focuses mainly on trespassers, the case as a whole clearly concerns the standard of care to lawful visitors, so the citation is directionally accurate.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors."

Sakellarios v. Fine, 361 Mass. 362 (1972.proposition: 5. **Sakellarios v. Fine**, 361 Mass. 362 (1972) – Establishing foreseeability as a key factor in negligence claims.
Sakellarios v. Fine, 361 Mass. 362 (1972.case_name: Carr v. Board of Appeals of Saugus
Sakellarios v. Fine, 361 Mass. 362 (1972.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns procedural requirements for appeals under a zoning statute (G.L. c. 40A, § 21) and how strictly those jurisdictional requirements should be construed. It does not address negligence, duty, or foreseeability, nor does it articulate any principle about foreseeability as a factor in negligence claims. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the stated negligence foreseeability proposition.
Sakellarios v. Fine, 361 Mass. 362 (1972.relevant_excerpt: “We have recently dealt with other jurisdictional aspects of this statute and have indicated our reluctance to construe strictly its provisions when to do so would be tantamount to attributing to the Legislature an intent ‘to create a series of procedural barriers reminiscent of an earlier age of the law.’ … We therefore hold that the above quoted portion of the statute is satisfied by the timely filing of the written notice with the town clerk.”

Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.proposition: 6. **Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637 (1996) – Clarification of causation in negligence cases.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The quoted text is a concurrence criticizing the majority’s discussion of causation and objecting to the court’s statement that earlier ‘keys left in ignitions’ cases are no longer persuasive due to an ‘expanded concept of causation.’ This passage does not itself clarify or affirm any new rule of causation in negligence; rather, it disputes the majority’s causation analysis and simply concurs in the narrower foreseeability holding. Without the majority opinion text, this excerpt alone cannot be said to support a proposition that the case clarifies causation law.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: "The court unnecessarily reaches out and declares that our cases involving keys left in ignitions are ‘no longer persuasive,’ ante at 640, because these decisions are inconsistent with our expanded concept of causation. I cannot join this conclusion. This view of causation is not mine as is evidenced by the fact that the decisions relied on by the court as enunciating this view were, with one exception, rendered without my acquiescence. I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiffs injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’"

Wendy\u2019s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison,.raw_text: Wendy’s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison, 410 Mass. 33 (1991)
Wendy\u2019s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison,.proposition: 7. **Wendy’s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison**, 410 Mass. 33 (1991) – Negligence per se due to statutory violations is actionable.
Wendy\u2019s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns suppression of a juvenile’s custodial statement and the requirement of an opportunity for meaningful consultation with an interested adult before Miranda waiver. It does not address civil negligence, statutory violations, or negligence per se in any way. Therefore, citing this case for the proposition that statutory violations create an actionable negligence per se claim is inaccurate and unsupported by the decision.
Wendy\u2019s of Mass., Inc. v. Davison,.relevant_excerpt: “As to juveniles at least fourteen years old at the time of the purported waiver, the prosecution must show that, before the disputed statement was obtained, the juvenile was advised of constitutional rights through a reading of the Miranda warnings and was afforded the opportunity to consult with an interested adult who was informed of, and understood, those rights.”

Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).proposition: 8. **Wallace v. Wilson**, 411 Mass. 8 (1991) – Liability when foreseeability of harm exists due to one’s actions or omissions.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).support_reasoning: The case holds that the parent owed no duty to the plaintiffs even though she knew or should have known minors were drinking and might pose a risk of harm. The court expressly refuses to impose liability based on foreseeability alone, emphasizing that her conduct did not create a legally cognizable risk for which the common law provides a remedy. Thus, Wallace v. Wilson stands for *no* liability in these circumstances, contrary to the proposition that it supports liability when foreseeability of harm exists.
Wallace v. Wilson, 411 Mass. 8 (1991).relevant_excerpt: “We reject the argument that a parent, who neither provides alcoholic beverages nor makes them available, owes a duty to travelers on the highways to supervise a party given by her minor child. We reach this conclusion even if [the defendant] knew or reasonably should have known that alcoholic beverages would be available. The defendant’s conduct did not create a risk of injury to the plaintiff for which we are prepared to say the common law should provide a remedy… We continue to adhere to the rule expressed in Langemann, and we think that that rule should apply here.”

Tourtellotte v. White\u2019s, Inc., 120.proposition: 9. **Tourtellotte v. White’s, Inc.**, 120 Mass. 465 (1876) – Duty to avoid creating conditions dangerous to others.
Tourtellotte v. White\u2019s, Inc., 120.support_reasoning: The case is about when a beneficiary (cestui que trust) may maintain an action at law for money had and received against a trustee after a trust has been settled and the amount due is certain. It does not discuss tort duties, negligence, or any duty to avoid creating dangerous conditions to others. Citing this decision for a general duty to avoid creating dangerous conditions misstates its actual holding and subject matter.
Tourtellotte v. White\u2019s, Inc., 120.relevant_excerpt: “It is well settled that a cestui que trust cannot bring an action at law against a trustee to recover for money had and received while the trust is still open; but when the trust has been closed and settled, the amount due the cestui que trust established and made certain, and nothing remains to be done but to pay over money, such an action may be maintained.”

Cotter v. Boston Edison Co., 42 Mass. Ap.raw_text: Cotter v. Boston Edison Co., 42 Mass. App. Ct. 189 (1997)
Cotter v. Boston Edison Co., 42 Mass. Ap.proposition: 10. **Cotter v. Boston Edison Co.**, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 189 (1997) – Explicit treatment of proximate cause in negligence claims.
Cotter v. Boston Edison Co., 42 Mass. Ap.support_reasoning: The provided opinion text is not Cotter v. Boston Edison Co. at all, but a different Massachusetts Appeals Court criminal case involving a defendant named Souza and issues of search, seizure, warrant scope, and amendment of a criminal complaint. It does not involve negligence, proximate cause, or civil liability, and therefore cannot provide explicit treatment of proximate cause in negligence claims. As such, this opinion does not support the stated proposition.
Cotter v. Boston Edison Co., 42 Mass. Ap.relevant_excerpt: The opinion focuses on search warrant validity: "The defendant contends that the search of his person pursuant to the 'any person present' language of the warrant violated his rights under the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution, art. 14 of the Massachusetts Declaration of Rights, and G. L. c. 276, § 1. ... Appellate review of a search based exclusively upon the 'any person present' language of a search warrant demands strict scrutiny of the warrant’s supporting affidavit in order to determine whether the search was valid."
